bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 3, 1902

div1.p: Reed writes a satirical letter concerning the appointment of the new Surgeon General, staff changes, and Kean's new position.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 3, 1902

opener.dateline:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
Septr 3, 1902

div1.p:
I am
delighted to have yours
of the 1st and to observe
that your erstwhile
cheerful spirit is
still unbroken- I can
well envy you the
enjoyment of those quiet
rural scenes of dear
old Albemarle, where
the gentle cricket
chirps and the mellow
pippin grows- Extract
therefrom, muy amigo
Carrissimo, all the de-
licious sweets that
spring therefrom, and, in
the meanwhile, add to your
store of Haemoglobin and
increase the anti-haemo-
lytic capacity of your
several body juices-
You will then be able
to tackle the New S. G.
with greater avidity
and better maintain your
grasp on his umbilical
depression! In this
connection, you may
securely rely on me
as an advocate whose
fondest hope is to see
you snugly nestled
in some inviting nook,
where the festive shekel
falls frequently, if not
steadily- “Torney the tar-
ryer & Willie the unwil-
ling”! How delightfully
you have “hit the nail”,
my dear friend, and
what a text for a
sermon! However,
while I do not see
that simply because
he fitted out the Relief
in time of need, my
old & good friend, Torney,
should expect to hold
on to Hot springs for-
ever; I might as well
say to you candidly. oh!
superintendente con cuore
duro, that a “lead-pipe
cinch” is a feeble expres-
sion for the more than
barnacle-like hold with
whichs T. will adhere
to his present station.
And for why? Simply that
he & his family are de-
vout Catholics, & you now
know how much religion
had to do with Teddy's
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
appointment of the pres-
ent or soon-to-be in-
cumbent of the high-
mighty office of S. G.
Put not your expecta-
tion, therefore, in Hot Springs
but rather turn to the
warm nest of “Willie
the unwilling”- Thereby
you can obtain a very
good station, remain
near the throne and
maintain your condition
of good, honest poverty!
No, Commandante de
los Ceritades de l'Isla
di Cuba, et cetera,
it was never intended
that a man of such a
generous disposition as
yourself, should ever
be the slave of “sordid
geld”! Remain poor
and do not allow riches
to choke the sunny Venis
of your jolly, big, heart!
I am more than de-
lighted to know that I
will have the pleasure
of seeing your dear
wife & yourself as
early as September
10th- Come right along
and bring Martha and
Robert, too- The flat
is yours as long as
you charming frau will do me the
honor to grace it!
Two days is too short
a time to stop in Wash-
ington, but we will
talk of that when
you come- O'Reilly,
I learn, will arrive
Saturday night, in time
to take charge on Sunday
at hight noon- We
hear that there is to be
a general upheaval. Ru-
mor has it that our dear
old friend, Smart, who
has been on a gorgeous
“Toot” for more than a month,
will be promptly retired.
Dewitt will unquestionably
be O'R's assistant- Girard
& Hoff will almost cer-
tainly hie them to the Phil-
ippines - and so the merry
wheel of time continues
to turn- Present my
love to your dear wife &
kiss the darling babies-
Till we meet again,
